Dalian National Laboratory for Clean Energy Dalian Institute of Chemical Physics Chinese Academy of Sciences 457 Zhongshan Road Dalian 116023 China A series of porous organic polymer with different concentrations of tri(4-vinylphenyl)phosphite (P(OPh)3) moieties were synthesized through the solvothermal synthesis technique. Their performance were investigated in 1-butene hydroformylation after metalation with metal species. The effect of the concentration of P(OPh)3 moieties and pore structure of the polymers on catalytic efficiency were investigated in detail. The polymer-based Rh catalysts demonstrated a decrease in catalytic activity and inverse trends in selectivity with the increasing concentration of P(OPh)3. More importantly, Rh/POP-PhPh3-BP-P(OPh)3-x catalysts containing biphephos moieties exhibited more excellent catalytic performance than the corresponding Rh/POP-PhPh3-P(OPh)3-x catalysts. And the optimal catalytic performance, a valeraldehyde n/i ratio of 60.4, a valeraldehyde TOF of 9589.9 h−1, and good catalytic stability were acquired for Rh/POP-PhPh3-BP-P(OPh)3–0.9 catalyst. The extraordinary catalytic properties are attributed to the formation of abundant active pentacoordinated hydridorhodium complexes, as demonstrated by in situ FT-IR experiments. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Porous organic polymers Hydroformylation of 1-butene Phosphite moieties concentration Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Hydroformylation, or the “oxo synthesis”, is the addition of carbon monoxide and molecular hydrogen to olefins to form aldehydes in a 100% atom-economical manner catalyzed by homogeneous metal complexes (Scheme 1 ) [1–7]. Currently, various phosphorus ligands modified Rh-based homogeneous catalysts are commonly used in this process on account of their remarkable activity and selectivity. Although homogeneous Rh-catalyzed hydroformylation has seen rapid developments, only a few examples are suitable for industrial application up to now. The drawbacks of cost-intensive recycling and losses due to leaching of rhodium still accompanies with this process and remains challenging in most cases. Consequently, researchers have sought to immobilize molecular hydroformylation catalysts on solid supports such as carbon [8–11], Al2O3 [12,13], nanoparticles [14,15], organic polymers [16,17] and silica-based materials [18–22] or in ionic liquids for biphasic systems [23] to result in heterogenizing homogeneous catalysts. Owing to the relatively low concentration of organic ligands in the vicinity of metal species, much lower activities and/or selectivities is a common problem for the traditional supported hydroformylation catalysts. Hence, the most promising strategy for gaining better catalytic activity and regioselectivity is to incorporate organic ligands into porous solid materials. Different Rh-complexes promoted by phosphorous ligands are immobilized onto solid supports via covalent coordination. For example, Chen and coworkers developed a phosphorus coordinated Rh single-atom catalyst with nanodiamond as support (Rh1/PNP-ND) for aqueous biphasic hydroformylation reactions. Rh1/PNP-ND afforded high branched regioselectivity with a b/l molar ratio up to 13.3:1, which outperformed Rh1/ZnO nanowires SAC and was comparable to the homogeneous counterparts [24]. Fan's group elaborated a triphenylphosphine-based functional covalent organic frameworks (COFs) synthesized through a Schiff base reaction and eclucidated its heterogeneous catalytic superiority in the heterogeneous hydroformylation of olefins [25]. Zhao et al. reported the encapsulation of atomically dispersed Rh catalysts inside porous monophosphine polymers for regioselective heterogeneous hydroformylation of alkenes. The optimized catalyst shows the linear aldehyde selectivity increases from 62% to 92% and excellent catalytic activity (one run TON at least 60,000) and good stability (reused for three runs) in hydroformylation of 1-octene [26]. Though some progress have been made using phosphorus ligands decorated Rh-based heterogeneous catalysts for hydroformylation of olefins, it still desiderates for exploring suitable phosphorous ligands concentration for efficient hydroformylation. Porous organic polymers (POPs) have exceptional properties such as high surface area, tunable pores and diverse organic functionalities, which are regarded as promising heterogeneous catalysts [27–31]. Among these, a new kind of POPs through solvothermal polymerization of vinyl-functionalized organic ligands, denoted as porous organic ligands (POLs), were constructed and widely applied in many fields [32–36]. More significantly, the industrial production and practical application of POLs have been successfully achieved by our group, which employs a heterogeneous Rh/POL-PPh3 catalyst for the hydroformylation of ethylene. Regrettably, POLs supported metal catalysts still have a low catalytic performance for the hydroformylation of 1-butene and the influence of P(OPh)3 moieties concentration and pore structure of the polymers on the catalytic performance have not been investigated in detail yet. Herein, we developed a series of porous organic polymers bearing various concentrations of tri(4-vinylphenyl)phosphite (P(OPh)3) moieties through the solvothermal synthesis technique (Schemes 3 and 4). By regulating the molar ratio of P(OPh)3 and 1,3,5-tri(4-vinylphenyl)benzene monomers and metallization with rhodium, ten new POP catalysts, which were designated as Rh/POP-PhPh3-P(OPh)3-x (x = 0.5, 1.0, 1.5, 2.0, 2.6) and Rh/POP-PhPh3-BP-P(OPh)3-x (x = 0.5, 0.9, 1.4, 1.9, 2.3), were systematically synthesized. Their catalytic performance were investigated in the hydroformylation of 1-butene and the effect of concentrations of P(OPh)3) moieties and pore structure towards catalytic efficiency were also studied and discussed. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials The synthesis gas (CO/H2 = 1/1, >99.9%) and 1-butene (> 99.9%) were supplied by Guangming Research & Design Institute of Chemical Industry. 2,2′-azobisisobutyronitrile (AIBN), Rh(acac)(CO)2 and divinylbenzene (DVB, 80%, containing 1000 ppm of TBC as stabilizer, Scheme 2 D) were purchased from Aladdin Biochemical Technology Co., Ltd and used without further purification. Toluene (AR) and tetrahydrofuran (THF, AR) were distilled over sodium/benzophenone under argon atmosphere. PCl3 was purchased from Tianjin Kemiou Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd. and purified by distillation under argon atmosphere before use. The synthesis of vinyl-functionalized biphephos ligand was carried out previously [33] (denoted as BP, Scheme 2A). 1,3,5-tri(4-vinylphenyl)benzene (denoted as 3v-PhPh3, Scheme 2C) and tris(4-vinylphenyl)phosphite (denoted as 3v-P(OPh)3, Scheme 2B) were synthesized according to the literatures [37,38]. 2.2 Methods 2.2.1 Synthesis of POP-PhPh3-P(OPh)3-x POP-PhPh3-P(OPh)3-x polymers with different P(OPh)3 moieties concentration were prepared from copolymerization of P(OPh)3 with 3v-PhPh3 at different ratios, where x represents the molar amounts of P(OPh)3 moieties in per gram of polymer. In a typical procedure, 0.2 g of 3v-P(OPh)3, 0.8 g of 3v-PhPh3 and 25 mg of AIBN were added to 10 mL of THF solvent at room temperature. The mixture was stirred for 10 min under an argon atmosphere. Then the solution was transferred into an autoclave at 100 °C for 24 h. After being dried under vacuum at 65 °C, a white solid monolith was obtained with 0.5 mmol/g of P(OPh)3 moieties concentration in the polymer skeleton and a nearly quantitative yield. The resulting sample was denoted as POP-PhPh3-P(OPh)3–0.5. POP-PhPh3-P(OPh)3–1.0. The synthesis of POP-PhPh3-P(OPh)3–1.0 follows the same route except for the copolymerization of 0.4 g of 3v-P(OPh)3 and 0.6 g of 3v-PhPh3. POP-PhPh3-P(OPh)3–1.5. The synthesis of POP-PhPh3-P(OPh)3–1.5 follows the same route except for the copolymerization of 0.6 g of 3v-P(OPh)3 and 0.4 g of 3v-PhPh3. POP-PhPh3-P(OPh)3–2.0. The synthesis of POP-PhPh3-P(OPh)3–2.0 follows the same route except for the copolymerization of 0.8 g of 3v-P(OPh)3 and 0.2 g of 3v-PhPh3. POP-DVB-P(OPh)3–1.0. The synthesis of POP-DVB-P(OPh)3–1.0 follows the same route except for the copolymerization of 0.4 g of 3v-P(OPh)3 and 0.6 g of divinylbenzene. POP-P(OPh)3–2.6. The synthesis of POP-P(OPh)3–2.6 follows the same route except for the polymerization of 1.0 g of 3v-P(OPh)3 monomer. 2.2.2 Synthesis of POP-PhPh3-BP-P(OPh)3-x POP-PhPh3-BP-P(OPh)3-x polymers with different P(OPh)3 moieties concentration were prepared from copolymerization of vinyl biphephos and P(OPh)3 with 3v-PhPh3 at different ratios, where x represents the molar amounts of P(OPh)3 moieties in per gram of polymer. In a typical procedure, 0.2 g of 3v-P(OPh)3, 0.8 g of 3v-PhPh3 and 0.1 g of 2v-biphephos were added to 10 mL of THF solvent under an argon atmosphere. Then AIBN (25 mg) was added and the mixture was stirred for a further 10 min at room temperature. Next, the mixture was transferred into an autoclave at 100 °C for 24 h. After being dried under vacuum at 65 °C, a white solid monolith with 0.5 mmol/g of P(OPh)3 moieties concentration in the polymer skeleton and a nearly quantitative yield. The resulting sample was denoted as POP-PhPh3-BP-P(OPh)3–0.5. POP-PhPh3-BP-P(OPh)3–0.9. The synthesis of POP-PhPh3-BP-P(OPh)3–0.9 follows the same route except for the copolymerization of 0.4 g of 3v-P(OPh)3, 0.6 g of 3v-PhPh3 and 0.1 g 2v-biphephos. POP-PhPh3-BP-P(OPh)3–1.4. The synthesis of POP-PhPh3-BP-P(OPh)3–1.4 follows the same route except for the copolymerization of 0.6 g of 3v-P(OPh)3, 0.4 g of 3v-PhPh3 and 0.1 g 2v-biphephos. POP-PhPh3-BP-P(OPh)3–1.9. The synthesis of POP-PhPh3-BP-P(OPh)3–1.9 follows the same route except for the copolymerization of 0.8 g of 3v-P(OPh)3, 0.2 g of 3v-PhPh3 and 0.1 g 2v-biphephos. POP-BP-P(OPh)3–2.3. The synthesis of POP-BP-P(OPh)3–2.3 follows the same route except for the copolymerization of 1.0 g of 3v-P(OPh)3 with 0.1 g 2v-biphephos. POP-BP-DVB. The synthesis of POP-BP-DVB follows the same route except for the copolymerization of 1.0 g of divinylbenzene with 0.1 g 2v-biphephos. 2.2.3 Synthesis of Rh/POP catalysts Rh/POP-PhPh3-P(OPh)3-x and Rh/POP-PhPh3-BP-P(OPh)3-x catalysts were prepared by impregnation method. In a typical preparation, 3.5 mg of Rh(CO)2(acac) was added to 20 mL of THF and the mixture was stirred under an argon atmosphere. Then 1.0 g of POP-PhPh3-P(OPh)3–0.5 was added into the above solution and stirred for 24 h at room temperature. The mixture was filtered and washed with excessive THF. After being dried under vacuum at 65 °C, the solid powder was obtained and denoted as Rh/POP-PhPh3-P(OPh)3–0.5. Other Rh/POP-PhPh3-P(OPh)3-x, Rh/POP-PhPh3-BP-P(OPh)3-x, Rh/POP-DVB-P(OPh)3–1.0 and Rh/POP-BP-DVB catalysts were prepared by the same procedure as Rh/POP-PhPh3-P(OPh)3–0.5 by impregnation of the corresponding polymers with rhodium precursor Rh(CO)2(acac) in THF solvent. The content of rhodium in the representative Rh/POP-BP-P(OPh)3–2.3 catalyst was determined by inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectrometer (ICP-OES) analysis. 2.2.4 Characterization of the catalysts Nitrogen sorption isotherms at 77 K were measured using a Quantachrome Autosorb-1 system. All the samples were outgassed at 120 °C for 12 h before the measurements. The specific surface areas were determined from the adsorption branch by the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) methods within the relative pressure range P/P0 of 0.05 to 0.30. The total pore volume was calculated at the P/P0 value of 0.995. The pore size distribution curves were obtained from the desorption points using the non-local density functional theory (NLDFT) method. About 30 mg of samples were employed when testing. The morphology and pore structure of the samples were captured by scanning electron microscopy (SEM), which were recorded with a JSM-7800F at an accelerating voltage of 0.01–30 kV. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images were done using a JEM-2100 instrument (200 kV). Inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectroscopy (ICP-OES) analysis was measured with an Anton Paar Multiwave 3000 emission spectrometer. The FT-IR apparatus for conducting the hydroformylation reactions were used as described in detail in our previous report [35]. For the infrared spectroscopic measurements, a Thermo Scientific Nicolet iS50 FTIR spectrometer with a MCT-A detector was used. All spectra were collected with 32 scans and the spectral resolution was set at 4 cm−1. After heat treatment in a flow of N2 at 353 K for 60 min, the background spectrum of the sample was acquired. Subsequently, a syngas (CO/H2 = 1:1, 0.1 MPa) was allowed to flow into the chamber at 353 K for 30 min. Then, a flow of N2 was introduced into the chamber at 373 K for 60 min. The situ FT-IR spectra of the sample were acquired after the treatment with different gasses. 2.2.5 Catalyst performance tests The hydroformylation experiments were carried out in a continuous flow fixed-bed reactor (I.D., 4.6 mm). The 1-butene were taken out of a gas bottle and its feed flowrate was controlled by plunger metering pump. The amount of 1-butene was exactly measured by a precision electronic balance. The feed volumetric flowrate of syngas (CO/H2 = 1:1) was adjusted through a mass flow meter. A gas back pressure valve was equipped to establish and control the pressure of reaction system by adjusting the exhaust emissions. The exhaust gas was analyzed online by a normalization method using an Agilent 3000A Micro GC apparatus equipped with four packed columns of Plot Q, molecule sieve, OV-1, Al2O3 and TCD as a detector. The liquid products were collected in a condenser cooled by circulating water at 278 K and analyzed off line by an internal standard method using an Agilent 6890A GC apparatus containing an HP-FFAP capillary column connected to a flame ionization detector (FID). Alcohol was used as an internal standard. The GC was calibrated by known amounts of substrates and products. The conversion of 1-butene was calculated by the following equation: n p e n tan a l + n b u tan e + n 2 − b u t e n e n 1 − b u t e n e , i n × 100 % , where npentanal is the mole amount of n-valeraldehyde and 2-methylbutyraldehyde, nbutane is the mole amount of butane, n2-butene is the mole amount of 2-butene and n1-butene, in is the mole amount of 1-butene added before reaction. The turn over-frequency (TOF) was calculated using the formula: T O F = n p e n tan a l n R h × t , where n pentanal, n Rh, t are the mole amount of n-valeraldehyde and 2-methylbutyraldehyde, the mole amount of Rh and the reaction time, respectively. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalytic performance In order to choose suitable crosslinker to modulate P(OPh)3 moieties density and pore structure in Rh-supported porous organic polymer catalysts, we examined the performance of Rh/POP-PhPh3-P(OPh)3–1.0, Rh/POP-DVB-P(OPh)3–1.0 and Rh/POP-P(OPh)3–2.6 in hydroformylation of 1-butene as shown in Table 1 . In the presence of Rh/POP-PhPh3-P(OPh)3–1.0, which adopted 3v-PhPh3 as a crosslinker, a high activity towords aldehydes formation (TOF = 5596.2 h−1), regioselectivity (l/b = 5.2) and chemoselectivity (90.1%) were observed over 24 h. An inferior activity and chemoselectivity were observed for two other catalysts in comparison with Rh/POP-PhPh3-P(OPh)3–1.0. Hence, 3v-PhPh3 was selected as the optimal structural monomer to elucidate the influence of P(OPh)3 moieties density and pore structure on 1-butene hydroformylation. First, the effect of P(OPh)3 moieties concentration on the catalytic performance of Rh/POP-PhPh3-P(OPh)3-x catalysts were studied at varied P(OPh)3 moieties concentration from 0.5 to 2.6 mmol/g as depicted in Table 2 . As the P(OPh)3 moieties concentration decreased from 2.6 to 0.5 mmol/g, the TOF towards aldehydes formation increased from 1102.2 to 5703.6 h−1, while the l:b ratio decreased from 6.3 to 4.0. Meanwhile, it is obvious that decreasing of the P(OPh)3 moieties concentration can enhance the selectivity of aldehydes from 63.4% to 86.5% even 93.8%. Basically, a higher P(OPh)3 moieties concentration in the Rh/POP-PhPh3-P(OPh)3-x catalysts facilitates the formation of n-pentanal but decreases the activity towards aldehydes, which corresponds well with the results reported in the homogeneous system [39]. This means that the P(OPh)3 moieties concentration played a key role for controlling regioselectivity and activity in Rh/POP-PhPh3-P(OPh)3-x catalysts. More importantly, high P(OPh)3 moieties concentration around the metal was conducive to the formation of suitable Rh-P coordination bonds and create more steric bulk in the rhodium complex. Alkene addition are inhibited by the steric hindrance and stronger CO bonding. Therefore, the overall rate of hydroformylation reaction decreases with the number of phosphite ligands coordinating to rhodium, whereas simultaneously the regioselectivity in terms of l/b ratio increases. Subsequently, since the Rh/CPOL-BP&P(OPh)3 catalyst have been investigated thoroughly in our previous work and exhibit moderate activity (2490.3 h−1) and high aldehyde selectivity (82.2%) and regioselectivity (l:b = 40.0), we introduce 1,3,5-tri(4-vinylphenyl)benzene as the crosslinker into the Rh/CPOL-BP&P(OPh)3 catalyst to regulate P(OPh)3 moieties concentration to improve its catalytic performance. As shown in Table 3 , the activity increased at first and then descended with P(OPh)3 moiety concentration increasing on the Rh/POP-PhPh3-BP-P(OPh)3-x catalysts, the l:b ratio displayed the similar variation. Surprisingly, the best results in terms of both TOF value and l:b ratio of pentanal were obtained at the P(OPh)3 moieties concentration of 0.9 mmol/g. Compared with the Rh/POP-PhPh3-P(OPh)3-x series catalysts, higher activity and l:b ratio of aldehydes were obtained on Rh/POP-PhPh3-BP-P(OPh)3-x catalyst with the same molar weight of P(OPh)3 moieties. That is to say, the catalytic performance of Rh/POP-PhPh3-BP-P(OPh)3-x catalysts were superior to those of corresponding Rh/POP-PhPh3-P(OPh)3-x catalysts. Moreover, the introduction of biphephos moieties in Rh/POP-PhPh3-BP-P(OPh)3-x could further enhance more steric hindrance and electron-deficient state in the coordination sphere of rhodium, which can favor the formation of linear metal alkyl intermediates and CO dissociation from the metal centers of the catalytic species, respectively, leading to higher catalytic activity and regioselectivity [4]. Stability is an important index for catalysts. The stability of the Rh/POP-PhPh3-BP-P(OPh)3-x and Rh/POP-PhPh3-P(OPh)3-x catalysts were tested for hydroformylation of 1-butene (Figs. 1 and S2). As shown in Fig. 1, the TOF of pentanal on the Rh/POP-PhPh3-BP-P(OPh)3–0.9 catalyst maintained stability at about 3000 h−1 during the period of 60–96 h. But the TOF decreased from 9590 to 3991 h−1 in the initial 60 h, since the Rh species might need time to find the most suitable coordinated state during the reaction. The l:b ratio of pentanal on the Rh/POP-PhPh3-BP-P(OPh)3–0.9 catalyst was more than 56 and can hardly change after 24 h of operation, While the l:b ratio on the Rh/POP-PhPh3-BP-P(OPh)3–0.5 catalyst decreased from 40.4 to 9.9. Clearly, increasing the concentration of P(OPh)3 moieties to 1.9 and 2.3 mmol/g, the TOF and l:b ratio of pentanal remained unchanged after 24 h of operation, suggesting that the stability of Rh/POP-PhPh3-BP-P(OPh)3-x series catalysts increased in proportion to the P(OPh)3 moieties concentration. In addition, the l:b ratio of pentanal on the Rh/POP-PhPh3-BP-P(OPh)3-x catalysts were much higher than those on the Rh/POP-PhPh3-P(OPh)3-x catalysts during the test time of 96 h, which may be ascribed to the introduction of biphephos moieties with considerable steric hindrance in the copolymer skeleton. Besides, the TEM images of Rh/POP-PhPh3-BP-P(OPh)3–0.9 catalyst before and after reaction (Fig. S1d and e) display that Rh species are highly dispersed on the surface of samples and no Rh nanoparticles could be detected. 3.2 Catalyst characterization studies As shown in Schemes 3 and 4 , POP-PhPh3-P(OPh)3-x (x = 0.5, 1.0, 1.5, 2.1 and 2.6) and POP-PhPh3-BP-P(OPh)3-x (x = 0.5, 0.9, 1.4, 1.9 and 2.3) were prepared using a solvothermal polymerization method, which affords these POPs in nearly 100% yield. The effects of the P(OPh)3 moieties concentration and pore structure on the hydroformylation were investigated and discussed hereinafter. The specific surface areas and pore structures of the synthesized POP-PhPh3-P(OPh)3-x and POP-PhPh3-BP-P(OPh)3-x were systematically investigated by N2 sorption isotherms collected at 77 K (Table 4 ). It is worth noting that the BET surface area and the total pore volume of the formed polymers increased along with the decrease of the concentration of P(OPh)3 moieties in the range of 0.5∼2.6 mmol/g. The POP-PhPh3-P(OPh)3–0.5 exhibited BET surface area as high as 1201 m2 g−1 and pore volume of 1.32 cm3 g−1, respectively, indicating that the P(OPh)3 moieties concentration played a key role in controlling the catalyst textures. With the increasing of P(OPh)3 concentration, the BET surface area and total pore volume of the POP-P(OPh)3–2.6 decreased to 860 m2/g and 0.96 cm3/g. As for POP-PhPh3-BP-P(OPh)3–0.5 polymer, the BET surface area and the total pore volume were 1133 m2 g−1 and 1.39 cm3 g−1, respectively. Similarly, as the P(OPh)3 moieties concentration increased, POP-BP-P(OPh)3–2.3 polymer gave the lowest BET surface area of 635 m2 g−1 and the total pore volume of 0.72 cm3 g−1. These results implied that an excessive concentration of P(OPh)3 moieties is not beneficial for the pore structures, and a relatively low concentration of P(OPh)3 moieties (approximately 0.5 mmol/g) is desirable for improving the specific surface areas and total pore volumes. While this developed high surface areas and hierarchical pore structure are regarded to be very favorable for the diffusion and mass transfer processes in catalysis, which lead to very high efficiency in the hydroformylation of 1-butene. As shown in Figs. 2 A and 3 A, the curves of five POP-PhPh3-P(OPh)3-x and POP-PhPh3-BP-P(OPh)3-x materials all exhibits a sorption behavior of type I with a sharp uptake of N2 at low relative pressure (P/P0 < 0.1) and type IV with obvious hysteresis loops at higher relative pressure (0.4 < P/P0 < 0.9), which indicated the hierarchical pore structures (the coexistence of micropores and mesopores) of these materials. According to the pore size distribution curve calculated from non-local density functional theory (NLDFT), the pore sizes (Figs. 2B and 3 B) are distributed predominantly at 0.70, 0.85, 1.38–1.44, 2–3 nm, indicating that POP-PhPh3-P(OPh)3-x and POP-PhPh3-BP-P(OPh)3-x copolymer has a hierarchical porosity as well. The high surface area and hierarchical porosity of POP-PhPh3-P(OPh)3-x and POP-PhPh3-BP-P(OPh)3-x polymers are favorable for the dispersion of catalytically active sites and diffusion of the reactants and products. Compared with POP-PhPh3-P(OPh)3-x, POP-PhPh3-BP-P(OPh)3-x have lower BET surface area and total pore volume. This might be explained by the larger molecular size of biphephos. Besides, POP-PhPh3-BP-P(OPh)3-x polymers have a high concentration of total P species (two kinds of P monomers), which are conducive to the formation of a suitable coordination environment for ligands and metal species by multiple coordination, and therefore improves the stability of the obtained catalysts. Furthermore, as for POP-PhPh3-BP-P(OPh)3-x polymer, it is obvious that high pressure area (P/P0=0.7 − 1.0) is shifted down to low pressure area (0.4–1.0) as the P(OPh)3 moieties concentration increased, indicating that the proportion of mesopore in the polymer was decreased (Fig. 2A). As shown in Fig. 3B, the pore size distribution of POP-PhPh3-BP-P(OPh)3-x moved towards micropores when the P(OPh)3 concentration increased. Moreover, increasing the P(OPh)3 moieties concentration from 1.0 to 2.1 mmol g−1, the pore size distribution of POP-PhPh3-BP-P(OPh)3-x displayed a similar variation tendency. It is reasonable to infer that P(OPh)3 moieties concentration would have an influence on the regioselectivity and activity via the P/Rh ratio and pore structure. The influence of the P(OPh)3 moieties concentration on the formation of active species was studied by in situ FT-IR spectra experiments. The specific assignments of the IR bands appearing on four representative species are listed in Table 5 . There is a fact that species of more CO and less P ligands coordinated with Rh are more active but less regioselective than those species of less CO and more P ligands, and more P ligands in the species is beneficial for the regioselectivity of hydroformylation [5]. As shown in Fig. 4 , for Rh/POP-P(OPh)3–2.6 catalyst, the ea-HRh(CO)2(P(OPh)3-S)2 (S stands for polymer skeleton) species of absorption bands at 1993 and 2044 cm−1 and HRh(CO)(P(OPh)3-S)3 species of absorption bands at 2044 cm−1 corresponded to a high l:b ratio of the aldehyde, while the HRh(CO)3(P(OPh)3-S) species at 2083, 2044 and 2018 cm−1 gave high activity. Interestingly, the intensity of the carbonyl absorption bands of the ea-HRh(CO)2(P(OPh)3-S)2 and HRh(CO)(P(OPh)3-S)3 species was stronger than those of HRh(CO)3(P(OPh)3-S) species, indicating that the concentration of ea-HRh(CO)2(P(OPh)3-S)2 and HRh(CO)(P(OPh)3-S)3 species were higher than those of HRh(CO)3(P(OPh)3-S) species. Therefore, high l:b ratio of the aldehyde but low reactivity were acquired by Rh/POP-P(OPh)3–2.6 catalyst, which was consistent with experimental results in Table 2. Five peaks at 2083, 2044, 2018, 2008 and 1993 cm−1 were observed on the Rh/POP-PhPh3-P(OPh)3–0.5, among which the peak at 2008 cm−1 was assigned to Rh(acac)(CO)(P(OPh)3-S)3 species and other absorption bands were the same as those on Rh/POP-P(OPh)3–2.6 catalyst. It was noteworthy that the peak intensities of HRh(CO)3(P(OPh)3-S), ea-HRh(CO)2(P(OPh)3-S)2 and HRh(CO)(P(OPh)3-S)3 species in samples with different P(OPh)3 moieties concentration vary remarkably, which might be ascribed to the disparity in the interaction between Rh with P(OPh)3 groups. Specifically, as decreasing the P(OPh)3 concentration, the intensities of peaks at 1993 and 2044 cm−1 were significantly weakened, while those at the bands of 2008, 2018 and 2083 cm−1 were enhanced, indicating that more HRh(CO)3(P(OPh)3-S) species were displayed on Rh/POP-PhPh3-P(OPh)3–0.5 catalyst, leading to higher reactivity but low l:b ratio of the aldehyde, which was in good agreement with experimental results in Table 2. Through the multiple comparing experimental studies, it is reasonable to suggest that decreasing the P(OPh)3 moieties concentration of the Rh/POP-PhPh3-P(OPh)3-x catalysts gradually increases the activity of hydroformylation, whereas simultaneously decreases the l:b ratio of aldehydes. The possible equilibrium between various hydrido rhodium complexes in the presence of CO and P(OPh)3 or biphephos after syngas absorption processes are proposed in Fig. 5 . Four peaks at 2083, 2044, 2018 and 1993 cm−1 were found on the Rh/POP-BP-P(OPh)3–2.3 catalyst, and there are more pentacoordinated hydrido complex ea-HRh(CO)2(BP&P(OPh)3-S) at 1993 and 2004 cm−1 and the HRh(CO)(BP&P(OPh)3-S) complex at 2044 cm−1 than HRh(CO)3(P(OPh)3-S) species at 2083, 2044 and 2018 cm−1, indicating that Rh species tend to coordinate with both kinds of P species in the copolymer skeleton. As the P(OPh)3 moieties concentration decreased from 2.3 to 0.9 mmol g−1, five peaks at 2083, 2049, 2018, 2008 and 1993 cm−1 were observed on Rh/POP-PhPh3-BP-P(OPh)3–0.9, among which the peak at 2008 cm−1 was attributed to Rh(acac)(CO)(BP&P(OPh)3-S) species and other absorption bands were the same as those on the Rh/POP-BP-P(OPh)3–2.3 catalyst. However, the proportions of these active species were different on catalysts with varied P(OPh)3 concentration (as shown in Fig. S3). Based on these findings, it can be concluded that the biphephos ligands with considerable steric hindrance and P(OPh)3 ligands with available adequate P concentration build a synergistic microenvironment with Rh species in Rh/POP-PhPh3-BP-P(OPh)3–0.9 catalyst, which facilitates the formation of abundant active pentacoordinated hydridorhodium complexes (as shown in Fig. S4). Therefore, Rh/POP-PhPh3-BP-P(OPh)3–0.9 catalyst exhibited the highest activity and regioselectivity in the hydroformylation of 1-butene. 4 Conclusion In conclusion, we have provided a facile method to adjust the P(OPh)3 moieties concentration and microenvironment by copolymerization of 3v-P(OPh)3 and/or vinyl biphephos with 3v-PhPh3 with different ratios for POPs. The obtained POP-PhPh3-P(OPh)3-x and POP-PhPh3-BP-P(OPh)3-x polymer possess abundant pore structure, adjustable surface area and large pore volume. They have been thoroughly studied in the hydroformylation of 1-butene after metallization of Rhodium. Through altering the P(OPh)3 moieties concentration and adjusting the types of phosphite ligands, different kinds of Rh-P active species were formed on these catalysts, leading to their different hindrance and abilities to coordinate with Rh ions to catalyze olefins hydroformylation reaction. The tested optimal catalyst of Rh/POP-PhPh3-BP-P(OPh)3–0.9 exhibited excellent performance in terms of activity and selectivity, which might be ascribed to the formation of abundant active Rh-P species, as demonstrated by in situ FT-IR experiments. The copolymerization strategy of 3v-P(OPh)3 and/or vinyl biphephos with 3v-PhPh3 makes it possible to simultaneously improve the selectivity and activity of olefins hydroformylation reaction on POPs supported catalysts, which also provides a new perspective for the design and construction state of art functional POPs materials. coredata.dc:description: A series of porous organic polymer with different concentrations of tri(4-vinylphenyl)phosphite (P(OPh)3) moieties were synthesized through the solvothermal synthesis technique. Their performance were investigated in 1-butene hydroformylation after metalation with metal species. The effect of the concentration of P(OPh)3 moieties and pore structure of the polymers on catalytic efficiency were investigated in detail. The polymer-based Rh catalysts demonstrated a decrease in catalytic activity and inverse trends in selectivity with the increasing concentration of P(OPh)3. More importantly, Rh/POP-PhPh3-BP-P(OPh)3-x catalysts containing biphephos moieties exhibited more excellent catalytic performance than the corresponding Rh/POP-PhPh3-P(OPh)3-x catalysts. And the optimal catalytic performance, a valeraldehyde n/i ratio of 60.4, a valeraldehyde TOF of 9589.9 h−1, and good catalytic stability were acquired for Rh/POP-PhPh3-BP-P(OPh)3–0.9 catalyst. The extraordinary catalytic properties are attributed to the formation of abundant active pentacoordinated hydridorhodium complexes, as demonstrated by in situ FT-IR experiments.
coredata.dc:title: Influence of phosphite ligands concentration on 1-butene hydroformylation over Rh-supported porous organic polymer catalysts
